If you‚Äôre in a position

Open up a fresh chart and ask ‚ÄúWhat would I think of this market if I weren‚Äôt in a trade?‚Äù 

If your view varies radically from how you‚Äôre positioned, it may be a good signal to manage the trade

Look through the PnL + R:R fog - the market doesn‚Äôt care

$BTC has been in a 6% range for 8 weeks 

Big consolidation before a BIG move

When it breaks, it'll go up or down - a lot

I have the world's best photoshop experts on standby to create fake PnL cards so I can LARP about catching the explosive move

GM https://t.co/PPKYrN7Sv3

Best things to do immediately after opening a trade:

--Go to the lowest time frame possible and panic over every tick/candle

--If underwater, curse yourself and beg the market gods to let you out at break even, vowing never to trade again

--If green, move targets higher and‚Ä¶

New trader: At horizontal and diagonal support, RSI oversold, MACD turning bullish, negative funding, flipped 69/420 Moving Average - scaled in 10% and waiting for confirmation but happy to be wrong 

Experienced trader: Dunno, looks decent, I punted

Market up: We're just getting started. Don't sell too early.

Market retraces: Took profit on leverage, still have COLOSALLY LARGE spot bags.

Market down: Hope you TPed, risk management is #1. Don't buy too early.

Market bounces: Did you buy the dip? What were you waiting for?
Doom loop of CT advice on trade management https://t.co/dwpTMiJz7c

I recommend having a friend/group with whom you discuss your trading, unfiltered

(Especially regarding mistakes, losing streaks, and bad trading generally)

Twitter is about posturing & plausible deniability

Being able to share and reflect without fear of judgment is powerful

"I'll take profit/sell on the way down" is tricky

Especially at volatile turns, your brain turns to mush once you give back a lot of uPnL

Suddenly chart looks bad and think "I should've sold but I'll wait for a bounce"

No bounce, more uPnL lost 
Panic, sell the bottom

Source: https://t.co/dk0zz8hWwH

Happy New Year!

I've been on CT since I was 20 - basically grew up here.

I really love this place and have made lifetime friends from it.

I know I'm a bit washed up but hopefully I can post some useful stuff from time to time. Or at least make you laugh.

Hope you crush 2024.

Just because a high time frame chart (monthly, weekly, daily) looks like a market has been without pullbacks

Doesn't mean that there have been no tradable pullbacks

Good reasons to trade: 
I am trading my edge 

Bad reasons to trade: 
I am bored 

I lost my last trade, market owes me a refund 

Looks like everyone else is making money, I wanna make some too

I missed the trade I was waiting for so I‚Äôll trade something else to compensate

When to consider taking profit:

1. If changes in unrealised PnL are significantly affecting your decision-making & emotions. 'Buy back' your peace of mind.

2. If you have 0 dry powder and would be paralysed by a pullback.

Basically 

These strong trends tend to lock you out if you‚Äôre waiting for a pullback

When the pullback inevitably comes 

You buy it too early and get liquidated anyway

The 2 ways to get high R:R setups that are realistic:

1. Entering as close as you can to where you're wrong (justifies a tight stop, risk is being too tight)

2. Entering HTF swing ideas via LTF execution (justifies a bigger target, risk is overmanaging/getting lost in sauce)

I helped build @Breakoutprop, which is live now.

When Mayne first asked me what I thought of evaluation-based prop trading I said it was a scam.

Poor execution, dodgy rules, and no transparency.

Instead of keeping it at that and continuing my peaceful life of losing money‚Ä¶

‚ÄúHow do you know if the level is going to hold?‚Äù

I can‚Äôt know.

I grow some balls and trade it.

If I make money, it held. 

If I lose money, it did not hold / the market is a fraudulent manipulated scam that targeted me specifically.

Follow a routine/mini ritual after a losing trade.
 
Clear your mind & recalibrate.

Walk, music, watch something, whatever.

Big mistakes often originate from a single small mistake.

If your old trade is dominating your thinking, you're not ready for a new trade.

CVD (Cumulative Volume Delta)

CVD is essentially a visualisation of market buys minus market sells.

Unlike the previous posts on funding rates and open interest, CVD is slightly more niche.

CVD is typically used to infer aggressive participation i.e. traders executing via‚Ä¶ https://t.co/yvN8WQSruy

This creates the illusion that everyone is trading massive size

On Adjusting to Trending Conditions

Some qualifiers before the main content:

1. There's never a good time to post this stuff. People love to infer that any post is some form of market commentary or hidden directional 'signal'. It is not, just take it for what it is.

2. There‚Ä¶

Funding Rates

The funding rate is the cost of holding an open position in a perpetual swap contract (perp).

It is usually calculated by the difference between the [price of the perpetual swap contract] and [price of a spot-based index].

If funding is positive, the perp price‚Ä¶ https://t.co/hx2Td8naoa

After a big move 

There‚Äôs a lot of reflection on the past (usually regrets)

And plenty of speculation about the distant future 

As a reminder: 

Your job is to trade today‚Äôs market with today‚Äôs prices 

Sounds trivial, but reframing = better decision making

On Confluence

Confluence is one of the most ubiquitous yet misunderstood terms in trading.

The ordinary definition of the term is "a coming or flowing together, meeting, or gathering at one point".

In terms of trading, it's usually meant to highlight several concurrent pieces‚Ä¶

$BTC

I've got 28.1-28.2 as a high time frame pivot

If we go up, I'll pretend I was long acceptance above it

If we go down, I'll pretend I was short obvious resistance

If we chop, I'll pretend I had the foresight to sit out of the PvP market

Thanks for coming to my Cred Talk https://t.co/fXx7UBurt4

Most people don't need to trade full time.

I'd even argue that most people would benefit from trading less frequently (past the beginner stage, at least).

Guys will spend 24/7 glued to their screens and at the same time tell you that conditions suck and to wait for easier‚Ä¶

Endless charts, indicators, price levels, news feeds

Looking for signal in a tsunami of noise

Reset.

1 or 2 assets
1 or 2 setups
1 or 2 time frames

Hone in your edge - it should jump out at you and almost beg to be traded

Treat everything else as a distraction

0 or 100

Started trading lower time frames again recently after a long break.

Immediate observations: 

--Uncomfortable being offside

--Poor ability to hold good entries even to conservative targets

--Managing trades unnecessarily (related to the previous point, usually in the form of‚Ä¶

‚ÄúJust wait for the bull market‚Äù 

Early bull market: Disbelief, short stuff, stay out because of HTF resistance 

Mid bull market: Dabble in some risk, fade breakouts & new stuff - PTSD too strong

Peak bull market: Go all in thinking it‚Äôs early/finally starting - buy the top https://t.co/FVv054l7Fl

Altcoin Trading in Late 2023

--Find low market cap, low volume, low liquidity coin with a perp listing (ideally team is desperate and/or price is rekt so you can get coins for cheaper)

--Corner spot supply (makes it harder for other parties to arb and MM generally as there's‚Ä¶

CT Translation Guide

I wouldn't long here = I am short

I wouldn't short here = I am long

No clear trade here = I am in a trade but it's going poorly and/or I am too embarrassed to post it

If it reclaims [price] it will look good = I am bearish below [price]
